description: Alteration of earlier land (“urine”), from Middle English land (“urine”), from Old English hland (“urine”), from Proto-West Germanic *hland, from Proto-Germanic *hlandą (“urine”), from Proto-Indo-European *klān- (“liquid, wet ground”). Cognate with Icelandic hland (“urine”), Norwegian Nynorsk land (“urine”).

entries.meaning: Aged urine, historically used by the Anglo-Saxons and others as fertilizer for high nitrogen content.

verbs.description: lant (third-person singular simple present lants, present participle lanting, simple past and past participle lanted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To flavor (ale) with aged urine.
(UK, dialect, Northern England) Obsolete form of lanterloo. (the card game)
Any of several species of slender marine fishes of the genus Ammodytes, including the common European species (Ammodytes tobianus) and the American species (Ammodytes americanus).
